narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The field trips were way too concentrated to the end of the semester -- and several took WAY too long/longer than was useful. It often felt like we were having a field trip just to have one and not to highlight some really useful lesson that we couldn't gain from a power point.
Field trip value: I think we could get more out of field trips if we had a lecture in class that prepared us for them technically more in depth, e.g. sewage treatment technology and processes.

The workload was disproportionate to other classes. 5 discussion sessions, 4 fieldtrips and 4 response papers, 4 homework assignment on top of a written finals took up a lot of non-class time commitments.

My biggest problem with this class is that it has a lot going on, and takes so much additional time outside of class designated to field trips and discussion sections. He also changed the course and/or discussion section meeting times often, which was frustrating. There's a lot going on apart from readings and lectures--section, fieldtrips, response papers, homeworks...and it's hard to keep track of it all. It's also more heavy on the latter half of the semester.

The book used as part of the course was great. It explained the concepts very clearly and complemented the lectures in a magnificent way. The instructor is very clear on lectures and puts a lot of effort in answering every student's questions, he also promoted discussions in the classroom and extra discussion sessions of the field trips. Very good course.

The course for me was a mix bag. Though it was well structured and useful it covered a 'lot' of materials.Besides, the class session was nearly three hours a week and also included a discussion session for about an hour and a field trip which was three to four hours. However, i got to learn more from the field trips. In addition, the class size was too big to make it more interactive.The instructor was excellent while the TAs were very helpful.

More time should be spent in class covering the field trips. As it stands, it feels as though they are tacked onto the syllabus and not integrated into the class well. Separate discussion sections are not helpful.
The problem sets were very useful. I think a few more of these towards the end would be good, and at least one fieldtrip in the earlier part of the course.
Qu 9a. The field trips cpuld be more spread out.

- I thought the number of fieldtrips was fine, but i think students had a little difficulty planning because they didnt start until the second half of the semester (this is to say, i think logistics would work out better if fieldtrips and required sections ran the course of the semester instead of only the second half).- In terms of out of class assignments, the response papers to the field trips, while a valuable exercise were perhaps a little monotonous. maybe giving one, or a list, of thought provoking questions or issues students might comment on would help to direct analysis a little more.- Prof Anisfeld is incredibly knowledgeable, seems committed to teaching, and covers a lot of material. sometimes lectures felt a little dry - maybe switching between methods of presentation (powerpoint/other) would be a good fix for this.- TAs were responsive, ran sections in a structured and directed fashion. Nathan in particular was excellent at synthesizing discussion.
I audited this course; and thus simply went to the lectures and did not work on homeworks or attend fieldtrips.

Great course - but content is very scattered! Would love for lecture notes to be more consistently organized, and also wish there was greater integration and tie-in with the fieldtrips. I think the fieldtrips are valuable in themselves, but just that they don't necessarily correlate with the classwork.

This is a very interesting class, however, it is clearly a survey class and to be comprehensive, a lot of material has to be covered. This leads to a somewhat superficial engagement with many topics. Also, the class was large and there were a few people with a lot of extraneous questions and comments, which made the pace of the class a little hectic - Shimi clearly tries very hard to both accommodate the questions as well as get through the material, but sometimes I wish he had been more consequent about cutting short discussions that might have interested some students, but not the large majority. However, his excellent preparation and accessibility to students made this a very good experience.
Water resource issues are important for anyone to know about, regardless of area of focus.
The variety of issues covered in the class.
Great teacher!
The field trips and discussion sessions
great overview of water resources. He truly understand water from an interdisciplinary perspective, which made this class great for natural and social scientists.
The Professor managed to cover a wide array of subjects in a coherent way which is not easy.
The discussion sessions, getting actualized in technologies and strategies for water management and learning about cases through out the world.
critically questioning what I had previously assumed about water resources&scarcity
Very Comprehensive
The pace is right and the lecture is well organized.
Shimi is a great instructor. Very clear in his delivery. Encourages discussion. Interested in his students' learning. I learned a lot.

Shimi is a wonderful professor and seemed to really know the topic well. The book was wonderful and easy to read. I also really appreciated how many student comments were listened to and dealt with during class.
For me the best thing about it was the field trips and discussions sessions that followed.
Field Trips
The reading and the lectures were great.

The field trips, or at least most of them. The class's topics were generally broad , so it was refreshing to see how water treatment and management was implemented at a local scale, and how individual firms or agencies deal with top-down policies from regulatory agencies.
Clarity, responsiveness of instructor, usefulness/applicability to management
Fieldtrips and problem set were very useful

This course provided an excellent survey of issues related to water resource management. The professor did a great of teaching the class and was particularly adept at following up on questions he did not have an immediate answer to.
- breadth of material covered- knowledge and interest of professor- quality of T.As
The comprehensiveness of the class gave a full sense of the issues with water.
The content. Shimmi covered a broad range of topics in a very thorough manner. The lectures were very detailed and the pace was excellent.
Fieldtrips.

Dr. Anisfeld (Shimi) is extremely receptive and responsive to students interests and inquiries. Though the class is a lecture, he is always willing to (and, I think, excited about) breaking out of lecture into more of a discussion. The greatness of the class is driven by Shimi.
The instructor - clearly knows a lot, but will also admit to not knowing something.

The information and issues that we discussed and studied were all very current and "up-to-date"... The field trips were a valuable chance to see actual cases of the many issues that we discussed in class.
The dairy field trip was amazing.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The class either needs to be a 4 credit course, or have greater flexibility in scheduling. Having all the field trips and required discussion sections AFTER spring break was total overkill. It made this the most time-consuming class at FES for me, and often felt perfunctory. Plus it was a bit inconsistent to require such significant outside of class time, when we didn't even get our homework assignments or discussion papers back prior to the next being due (or even before the class ended for the term). The outside of class activities need to be spread more evenly throughout the semester, and planned for from the very beginning. The discussion sections were scheduled by a raising of hands one day in class and conflicted with several other FES classes, leaving VERY little flexibility for many of us.
Some content too general. More case studies, perhaps? More hard skills learning. More economics.
The evening discussion sessions should be dropped. They are an overkill.More numerical problems would be nice.
too many rigid requirements with the field trips&discussion sections. lectures a bit boring; hard to concentrate.

The class was too big to have productive discussions. Discussion sessions helped but the discussion among students during class time weren't that engaging always, mostly because there were too many people.

I thought this class was a bit too broad and not enough deep. I would have preferred if we left off a topic or two in order to go into greater depth with something.Also, the field trips shouldn't be so backloaded. The first half of the semester required little commitment, then at the end of the semester we had two lectures, one field trip, one discussion section, and one review paper due each week. Gotta spread that out!
The time commitment for the class very strenuous while the class size was too big to make the class interactive.
Field trip and discussion session time commitment was too much.
The way field trips and discussion sections are used -- wasn't helpful at all.

A change in the structure of the lectures. Questions were openly invited and encouraged, but this had the disadvantage of allowing for many superfluous questions which slowed the general pace of the lecture and the content reviewed. Of course, this is the fault of the students more than the professor.
The spacing of the field trips. Also, the out of class structured time commitments were fairly arduous.
For some of the topics it would help to have more images in the slides.
Guidance on the purpose or focus going into field trips. i.e. what we should be looking for so the the information is not too broad.

The field trips are an important component of the course. The field trip response papers and the discussion sessions are overkill. Either response papers or discussion sessions would be appropriate, but not both. Being required to attend a discussion session for field trip you didn't attend is not helpful and leads to confusion. Field trip response papers are helpful because completing them requires you to reflect on the field trip, but they should not be graded - credit should be received for completing them. Grading response papers, and specifically grading the papers on how well they "critique" a field trip is not a good idea. This approach works for things like the Zyg Platter field trip or the Water movie, but does not really work for the actual field trips. You're asking people who have little information or experience to critique something, which puts them in a "critique" mindset instead of a "learning" mindset. It is possible to respond to something without critiquing it. One certainly has a response to a stormwater basin, but asking someone to specifically write a critique of a stormwater basin (or stormwater management in general based on literally, seeing two stormwater basins) is flawed. If they have a critique to share that's fine, but the grading system shouldn't be designed to require a critique. Ultimately, the people who build the systems (engineers, planners, etc.) end up not listening to people who have learned to critique with little background knowledge. Teach to learn, think, reflect and yes critique - but don't force artificial critique.

- perhaps more depth if possible (i dont know if it is given that it is a survey course)- perhaps a little more hands on work?- some of the problem sets could use a little refining- changing up lecturing style, away from powerpoint sometimes.

I would try to improve the pace of the course. So many people asked questions during class it was difficult to keep up with the syllabus. Also, I would try to make the class a little more interactive, by adding short homework assignments or making lecture more interactive.
The slides (though excellent) sometimes were hard to follow in order. A way of structuring the slides would be very helpful.

Discussion sections poorly run and managed - a lot better preparation could be used both in terms of the TAs (material they can work on to engage class) and for students (have questions you will be asked, make sure students know they will be graded on contribution or participation).
I wish field trips, which, in terms of time, were a considerable commitment, had been better spaced throughout the class. They all came at the end.

Sometimes I wish Shimi had spoken more of his own research, to give some more depth in an area of expertise. The class is good, but sometimes survey classes can be frustrating - one leaves with a little information about a lot, and it would maybe have been good to engage more deeply with one topic for a week or so.
The RWA field trip was not so engaging.The course requires a lot of out of class time, but I think in the end it was manageable.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Mostly by email, but helpful.
Always helpful.
Both professor and TAs where in good disposition to attend questions.
Good.
Both TAs did an excellent job, showed availability and were very helpful.
n/a
great
Both TA's were great. Knowledgeable, helpful, available.
Both the instructor and TAs were helpful.
Great. The Professor and TAs were very helpful with our questions.
All were great and responsive.
Excellent, both TAs and the instructor were responsive and helpful with both administration and content
very good
Adequate
Although I didn't reach out for help, Prof. Anisfeld seemed particularly open to providing assistance if needed.
excellent
It was great. Shimmi answered all of our questions with great detail.
Both were very receptive.
Always helpful and accessible, and holds extensive office hours!

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I took this class because of the bin requirements -- I'm glad I took it, but it was super labor intensive for a mandatory class.
Fit well. Water will be important and I'm interested in how to think about it. This course provided me with the basic tools to think more comprehensively.
This class should be part of the intermediary layer in our new curriculum (water, energy, silvi-culture etc). It is an introductory course but already heavily interdisciplinary.
did it just for the bin, so it doesn't fit
Learning about water issues is helpful overall.
It gives me a comprehensive and fundamental understanding of water resources. Really helpful
This is a core class for my concentration.

This course was a very good connection between science and management. I felt that this course helped me to have a different perspective on topics I was familiar with, but had never considered from a management viewpoint.
The course is a general introduction to water resources and covers everything. However, i took this class as a fulfilment of the bin requirement but found it much interesting than anticipated.
Fits in really well and is definitely an important class at FES.
It is a good introductory class.

I am interested in agriculture. This course sheds light on the impacts of water withdrawal&discharges relative to agricultural water use as well as its competition with industrial and municipal water use.
informed independent research, and added to general management understanding.
I am interested in law and policy. The course fits well into understanding the issues and the interests that need to be managed to meet goals of water availability.
I was generally interested in getting a broad background on water issues. This is one of FES's most useful courses and does a great job at integrating science, policy, and economics.

Doesn't completely cover what i will be doing the future (sustainability consulting) but was great in giving me broad knowledge of this area, which I think is a very critical component of future work in the field.

I think this class is important as an introduction to WRM for students without previous experience in this topic. This should be made clear in the first class (I think it was made clear, but I've seen in some other classes that students don't seem to grasp this kind of advice early on and then later some tend to complain that they didn't expect a class to turn out this way, even if the instructor announced at first - I know it's frustrating to deal with this, but maybe next time make it EXTRA clear that it's a survey class)
This will probably be my only class on water, so it fulfills a valuable role as a survey course with a lot of critical thinking components.
This course is useful for land use planning.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Bins.
see above
I wanted to learn how water resources management really works.
Bin + Shimi + I wanted to find out what this water crisis is about.
did it for the bin
requirement.
I am interested and majored in water issues
This is a core class for my concentration.
I'd hoped to gain some knowledge about management of water, not simply science.
I took it as a bin requirement.
This course satisfies Bin 1.
Because I'm interested in learning more about water.
To improve understanding of how water resources are measured and regulated.
To fulfill a bin, but i would recommend it to most MEM students. The frameworks can be applied across many natural resource management questions.
Because i wanted to be well rounded in knowledge pertaining to water resources management
Foundational natural resource knowledge
to inform independent work, interest, potential bin fulfillment

I needed to fulfill a bin requirement. This course was one of two choices. I chose this one because I was interested in site remediation and I thought knowing a little bit about water would be relevant. I got much more out of the course than I expected.
I wanted a structured approach to the subject matter, though I had been working on water issues for three years.
Last FES core credit before graduation; I heard Shimi had a great reputation.
Because I had heard great things about Shimi, because I'm interested in urban water management, and because I needed to fulfill a requirement.
I've gathered information from my previous work and interest in WRM and wanted to consolidate my knowledge by gaining a good basis of understanding for policy, legislation and management.
I needed to fulfill a distribution requirement.
I was curious, and it fulfilled a bin requirement.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: More time than I expected, but a good course.
In part. Would have liked improvement on field trips, see above, and more hard skills, see above.
Yes
Yes
Yes, and the course was better than I expected.
not really
Yes
yes.
Yes
Yes and much more. The field trips were highlights of the course.
Yes
Somewhat. Readings were great, but it was too broad to be useful in some respects.
Yes, although the assignments associated with it were less than challenging.
Yes
Yes and No. While the class did fill in some gaps, i wish we could have learned some topic more indepth. Perhaps replcing some of the response papers for mini-research papers.
Yes, though I was hoping that it would include more management specific technical skills
The course lived up to my expectations. It was exactly what I thought it would be.
more or less. see above suggestions
Exceeded them.
Yes.
Teaching style was confusing and lecture slides very disorganized. Other than that, I think there was great content - just at times overloaded with redundant information and not always clear.
Yes.
Yes - although it would have been great to have one or two topics to discuss more in depth
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: An intro to the variety of water issues and management challenges, yes.
see above.
Yes
Yes
Yes
same as 17!
Yes
Yes.
Yes

I didn't expect more from the class as i saw it to fulfil a bin. But, information and knowledge shared was much more than i anticipated while the field trips and response papers were highlights of the class.
Yes, and more.
Yes
YEs and No. See above
Yes.
yes
Yes.
Yes, I learned the general topics and tools to address water management globally and locally.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I did not work in a group.
Not Applicable
Yes we did some of the problem sets in groups. It good because you talk things through

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: remember that the schedule changes dramatically after spring break.
Good class. Link it with water economics class and or water pollution class.
it was okay; not sure how it compares to other courses in this bin. you might have to take it if you're like me. if you don't have to take it, don't take it unless you're really interested in water
Keep up with readings and ask lots of questions.

The course is a general introduction to water resources and covers a lot of materials. The field trips and discussion are very useful in one's learning of the topis but be sure to commit yourself time wise.
Its a great learning experience if you are interested in issues relating to water. Shimi uses a very comprehensive text that is easy to read and very informational.
I would tell them to take it, but to be very aware of the time commitment involved in not only going to class and field trips, but also discussion sections.
Consider this a general survey course on water resources; it is not a scientific course, nor is it a policy course.
Really try to space out the field trips in advance; plan to spend a lot of time at the end of the semester; read before lecture.
Its a good class to take, however, if you are really interested into the topic try and work out and independent study with shimi
i would suggest doing as much of the reading as you can, for your own fulfillment.
Be prepared to engage in the lectures in an intelligent way. Also prepare for the field trips to get the most out of them.
The class is pretty full; sign up early for the field trips so you can make the most out of the topics that most interest you.
Ask questions. A lecture is a lecture, but it's great to engage Shimi in relevant issues.
Shimi is great. Take any of his classes. Take advantage of the time he gives to students - it's uncommon here and an extremely valuable resource!

The out-of-class time commitment is high, but it is all doable. The homework assignments were educational and not too long or difficult, and the field trips are mostly extremely engaging. You can learn a lot.
